input: What is CPIMS
What does CPIMS do
Why was CPIMS created
purpose of CPIMS
CPIMS purpose
CPIMS use
responses:
CPIMS is a child-focused database that has been designed to:
1. Facilitate monitoring and evaluation of child protection interventions in Kenya, inform policy and evidence based decision making
2. Provide access to accurate, timely and reliable aggregate-level child protection data
3. Facilitate record keeping and information management on individual cases of child protection
4. Track vulnerable children longitudinally and geographically to ensure continuity of care and protection, including children in institutional care
5. Facilitate appropriate information sharing between stakeholders and service providers in the best interest of the child
6. Be flexible and extensible over time to cater for emerging needs in the children sector

input: Who does the CPIMS target
Who is the CPIMS created for
CPIMS beneficiaries
responses:
It targets;
1. Children separated from or lack adult family guardians (e.g. abandoned, street living children, trafficked, lost, orphans without family care, children with parents in prison, child headed households)
2. Children in residential institutions (statutory or charitable)
3. Children affected by VANE: Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation – (physical abuse, sexual exploitation, sexual assault, defilement, incest, emotional abuse, neglect, female genital mutilation and other retrogressive cultural practices)
4. Has experienced trauma from involvement in emergency situations e.g. man-made and natural disasters
5. Living in risky family setting e.g. drug abuse in family, previous history of abuse or harmful practices in family
6. Children in vulnerable families – living with chronically sick caregiver(s), or caregivers who are elderly or disabled to an extent that affects care of children
7. Children in conflict with law, child offenders
8. Child with severe health or disability issues (disability (mental, physical, albinism), living with HIV/AIDS, drug user)
9. Child marriage, pregnancy, children who have given birth
10. Child labour (domestic, agricultural, industrial, fishing, mining, street work)
11. Children out of school due to truancy or delinquency
12. Children subject to custody disputes, maintenance disputes, paternity disputes
13. Children in need of social assistance to fulfil legal rights – birth registration, medical insurance, inheritance

input: Not able to follow-up discharged kids
discharged
discharge
Can I understand why on dashboard I have 5 children who are indicated as discharged yet they are still with us
responses: Sometimes there is a delay in the status upgrade but we will check it up

For a case to 'disappear from pending' as you put it,you must have provided at least one service by managing encounters.If you don't manage any encounter but you manage a service,referral or court session,it still remains pending. So,there is a great chance that in some cases you have not managed an encounter hence them remaining as pending.

responses: Use the forgot password functionality to reset.

Step 1: Go to reset password link from login page or directly from here https://childprotection.go.ke/accounts/password/reset/
  Step 2: Enter you email address and a link will be sent to the email
  Step 3: Click on the link in the email to reset password
  Step 4: Enter new password and repeat it and click submit (This will NEVER ask you for your old password and if it does then it means you are already logged in to CPIMS)
  Step 5: Log in with your new password in Step 4 and if it requests after log in to change password then your old password will be the one in Step 4.

Please try logging in from another machine and report if it works. You can even use your phone. www.childprotection.go.ke is up and running. Please confirm that your internet connection is active and try to logging in from another computer.

input: complexity needed for passwords
password complexity
complexity for passwords
password syntax
syntax for passwords
responses:
1.at least 8 characters, at least 1 digit(s)
2. at least 1 lower case letter(s)
3. at least 1 upper case letter(s)
4. at least 1 special character(s) such as as *, -, or #
The password must have at least 8 characters, at least 1 digit(s), at least 1 lower case letter(s), at least 1 upper case letter(s), at least 1 special character(s) such as as *, -, or #

input: What should I do if I'm unable to access the CPIMS system due to a computer crash?
Are there any warning signs that my computer might be about to crash, and how can I recognize them?
Can you provide any troubleshooting tips for fixing a computer that has crashed
What should I do if my computer crashes while I'm using the CPIMS system
crash
system crashed
lag
system
is slow
responses: if your computer has crashed and you need technical assistance, I recommend reaching out to your organization's IT support team or contacting a professional computer repair service. They should be able to assist you with resolving the issue and getting your computer back up and running.
Contact the IT team for assistance

If your computer crashes while using the CPIMS system, try restarting your computer and reopening the CPIMS system. If the issue persists, contact the organization's IT support team for further assistance.

To prevent your computer from crashing while using the CPIMS system, make sure that your computer meets the system requirements for the software and keep your computer's operating system and antivirus software up-to-date. Additionally, avoid running too many programs or tasks simultaneously as this can strain your computer's resources

If your computer has crashed, try restarting it and running a virus scan to check for any malware or viruses that may be causing the issue. If the issue persists, contact your organization's IT support team for further assistance.

Depending on the cause of the computer crash, you may or may not lose data or information stored in the CPIMS system. It is always a good idea to regularly backup your data to prevent data loss in the event of a computer crash

responses:
1. Institution population appears on the dashboard (Boys/Girls) 
 2. To Search for a child just use the search bar appearing on all pages at the top put child name and click enter. 
  3. In child search results there is a history button to give child past CPIMS interactions (past cases, institution placements and any program enrollments like USAID OVC program, PSSB)
 4. In case record detail and institution details (Edit, Print, pdf) has been added. The print button is now functional. 
 5. when your password is changed you will recieve a CPIMS internal notification.
  6. When you transfer a child to another insitituion the users in the other SI will be notified.

For a case to 'disappear from pending' as you put it,you must have provided at least one service by managing encounters.If you don't manage any encounter but you manage a service,referral or court session,it still remains pending. So,there is a great chance that in some cases you have not managed an encounter hence them remaining as pending.

 4. In case record detail and institution details (Edit, Print, pdf) has been added. The print button is now functional.
 5. when your password is changed you will recieve a CPIMS internal notification.
 6. When you transfer a child to another insitituion the users in the other SI will be notified.

input: Where does the CPIMS get its referrals from?
Referrals of CPIMS
CPIMS referrals
Where does the CPIMS get its referals from?
Referals of CPIMS
CPIMS referals
responses:
It tracks referrals such as;
1. Referrals from SCCO to NGOs (e.g. legal aid, support services)
2. Referrals from NGOs to SCCOs
3. Referrals to other government agencies (court, cash transfer, education authorities, Presidential bursary fund, health facilities)
4. Court orders made in relation to children’s cases, including orders related to placements and adoptions, committal to institutions, supervision.
